newsitem.title: JAPAN: DKB says informed foreign regulators about loans.
newsitem.headline: DKB says informed foreign regulators about loans.

text.p: Katsuhiko Kondo, president of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, said on Thursday that the bank has informed overseas regulators about loans linked to racketeers.
Kondo said the bank had not been told by any overseas regulators that they would annul DKB's business licences.

Kondo was appearing before the budget committee of the Lower House of parliament as an unsworn witness regarding questionable loans to racketeer Ryuichi Koike, the figure at the centre of a payoff scandal involving Nomura Securities Co Ltd.

Kondo told the committee that he had begun to doubt the credibility of the DKB's internal investigation which found that questionable loans were made to a company owned by Yoshinori Koike, the younger brother of Ryuichi Koike.
"I'm getting a feeling that there might be the presence of Ryuichi Koike" in the loans provided to his younger brother and his company, he said.
DKB has admitted extending a total of 27.5 billion yen in loans to the company run by Koike's younger brother and his company, but does not think loans were made to Koike.
DKB has also admitted concealing non-performing loans to them during Ministry of Finance (MOF) inspections in 1990 and 1994.
The two Koike brothers were arrested last month on suspicion of taking about 50 million yen in illegal payments from Nomura Securities.
Kondo told the committee that the loans to the younger Koike and his company were extended through the bank's general affairs section.
The general affairs sections of Japanese companies traditionally handle any dealings with racketeers, financial industry sources said.
Kondo said he felt deeply responsible for not recognising earlier the existence of the questionable loans.
On May 23, top executives of DKB, including Kondo, announced that they would resign after the bank's annual shareholders' meeting on June 26 to take responsibility for the loan scandal.
